page.title: 02DALMALLY CHURCH
page.content: Dalmally has many features of historical interest. The main one within the village is the church. The church that stands in Dalmally today is the third to be built in the village. It was built in 1807 and is an octagonal shape. The timber which holds up the roof was the last of the old forest in Glenstrae. The slates on the roof were brought from Easdale Island. In the bell tower there is a bell which weighs 190 pounds, it used to hang from a tree but was later moved into the bell tower. One thousand and fifty five pounds was spent to furnish the church in 1809 most of this furniture still remains in the church. Each bay of the octagon contains on large arch pointed window one having a wooden frame. The church was paid for by the fourth Earl of Breadalbane.
